;民主党和共和党周五达成协议以避免严重的美国债务违约 –并赢得了一些额外的喘息空间，因为财政部推迟了政府资金用完的日期。

;

;财政部长珍妮特耶伦表示，可怕的 X 日期现在是 6 月 5 日，而不是 6 月 1 日，如果国会未能提高债务上限，授权政府增加借款。

;

;然而，耶伦警告说，最后期限的延长不会改变结束国会僵局的紧迫性。

;

;“等到最后一刻才暂停或提高债务上限可能会对企业和消费者信心造成严重损害，提高纳税人的短期借贷成本，并对美国的信用评级产生负面影响，”她在一封信中说超过共和党人凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy)。

;

;有一丝乐观情绪。据未经证实的美国媒体报道，一项正在形成的协议将包括一项将政府的借款权限延长两年的协议，这意味着在 2024 年总统大选之前不会重演当前的戏剧。

;

;然而，民主党人会共和党要求全面限制社会保障和其他国内计划的支出，因此必须做出让步。

;

;众议院议长麦卡锡告诉记者，谈判代表“取得了进展”，但补充说：“在全部达成一致之前，什么都没有达成一致

;

;历史上首次美国债务违约可能引发股市抛售、大量失业和经济衰退，并对全球经济产生重大溢出效应。

;

;中国机构首先因债务上限问题扩大而下调美国信用评级

;

;国际货币基金组织总裁克里斯塔琳娜·格奥尔基耶娃引用了她表示“美国经济已证明具有弹性”的新数据，但敦促“迅速解决”债务问题。

;

;“我们认为美国国债市场是全球金融体系的锚点，这个锚点需要牢牢抓住，”她说。

;

;随着国家举行为期三天的纪念活动周末假期，国会议员将离开华盛顿进行为期 10 天的休会。就连总统乔·拜登——令他自己党内的一些人感到惊愕的是——也将前往他在特拉华州的戴维营度假胜地和他的私人住宅。

;

;然而，财政部副部长沃利·阿德耶莫告诉 CNN，拜登和

;

;“总统决定了，议长已经说过了，我们必须在 6 月之前完成一些事情，”阿德耶莫说。 “总统致力于确保我们与共和党进行真诚的谈判以达成协议，因为替代方案对所有美国人来说都是灾难性的。”

;

;周四，拜登还试图安抚全国，说：“不会有违约。”

;

;提高债务上限是一项年度会计操作，通常会在相对较短的情况下通过。它只是让政府继续借钱来支付预算中已经产生的账单。

;

;今年，越来越强硬的共和党决定将债务上限变成迫使拜登下台的筹码支持民主党最喜欢的支出优先事项。

;

;共和党人称之为对 31 万亿美元的国债负责。白宫指责控制众议院的反对党将经济作为人质。

;

;民主党少数党领袖哈基姆杰弗里斯周四在众议院抨击共和党人，指责他们冒着“危险的风险”在他们制造的危机中违约”。

;

;麦卡锡说共和党人和白宫“有时间”达成债务协议

;

;经济学家花了几个月的时间提出经济灾难的前景应该政府违约，军方高级官员周四发表了他们自己的可怕预测，警告称这场危机将对军队产生“重大负面影响”。

;

;参谋长联席会议告诉记者。

;

;麦卡锡指出，美国有线电视新闻网 (CNN) 最近的一项民意调查显示，60% 的人支持在削减债务的情况下提高债务上限，尽管 51% 的受访者在新蒙茅斯大学调查表示，他们希望将这两个问题分开。

;

;虽然立法者正在休会，但麦卡锡表示，如果他们需要返回投票，他们将提前 24 小时收到通知。

;泰国一直在暗示与中国携手开发新能源和数字化的想法东南亚市场，此举将把双边合作提升到旅游和热带水果以外的新层面。

;

;泰国驻华大使 Arthayudh Srisamoot 最近提到的这个想法也可能对北京有利，因为世界第二大经济体将东南亚国家联盟 10 个成员国和区域全面经济伙伴关系协定 15 个成员国视为美国市场的替代品。

;

;Arthayudh 表示，泰国政府正在关注新的产业和创新产品，因为它寻求与中国公司在老挝和越南等国家共同投资风力涡轮机、水力发电大坝和太阳能农场。

;

;“这是中国商人和泰国商人共同经营的一个例子5 月中旬，他在澳门举行的全球人才论坛期间表示，正在为新能源领域的第三国提供帮助。

;

;Arthayudh 援引历史联系，特别指出了合作的潜力中国大湾区是华南地区重要的增长引擎，也是新能源和数字化发展的基地。

;

;由香港、澳门和深圳、广州等九个内地城市组成的经济开发区旨在成为中国领先的增长和创新中心，已经拥有电信巨头华为、新能源汽车生产商比亚迪、互联网巨头腾讯和无人机制造商大疆创新等领先品牌。

;

;东盟是中国最大的出口目的地今年前四个月，超过美国和欧盟。

;

;泰国如何吸引比日本或澳大利亚更多的中国游客

;

;中国制造商正在东南亚建设许多工厂拥有 6.6 亿人口的泰国，许多中国科技公司扩大了在该地区的市场占有率。

;

;泰国是东盟第二大经济体，历来是中国游客最喜欢的目的地– 今年预计将有 500 万人访问该国 – 并且是进口大米和热带水果的主要来源。

;

;它还是中国发展泛亚高速铁路网的重要合作伙伴将从中国云南省省会昆明延伸到新加坡。

;

;“我认为现在创意[和]新产业非常突出，”Arthayudh。 “你知道，我们谈论的是清洁能源、一次性废物的管理。并且有很多中国公司将所有这些废品制成建筑材料、砖墙和塔楼。”

;

;国际能源署去年的一份报告称，东盟成员国向可持续能源的过渡可以在新兴的清洁能源经济中提供“更大的商机”。

;

;大使说，广东省省长王伟中将于下月底访问泰国，他希望双方能借此机会达成一致

;

;中国将在 6 月吃到第一批本地榴莲。马来西亚、泰国的主导地位是否面临风险？

;

;中国最大的出口省份广东省与泰国之间的年度对话机制已经实施了 20 年，在过去两年中年度会议升级为部长级会议

;

;Arthayudh 表示，泰国人仍然主要依靠现金和信用卡进行支付，并依靠铅笔或水彩进行设计，这使其成为“一个更传统的国家”，“在这方面有很多东西可以向中国学习”充分利用数字概念的条款”。

;

;“我认为东南亚国家有点传统——[如果]你去印度尼西亚、老挝、柬埔寨，他们仍然不知道数字生活方式，”他说，暗示着巨大的发展潜力。 “[如果]你去缅甸，他们仍在使用半个世纪前的技术……所以我认为前进的方向是数字化。”

;

;在与助理外交部长农荣的会谈中3 月，Arthayudh 表示，全面恢复两国各层级交流将“深化包括区域合作在内的多边领域的协调与合作”。

;

;世界银行 5 月 16 日发布的一份报告称，泰国的创新是技术工人短缺、科学生产薄弱以及融资渠道有限限制了中小企业的发展。

;

;“当我们审视我们与中国的关系时，它不仅仅是数字或创意产业，”Arthayudh 说。 “农业是泰中合作的重要领域。

;

;“当然，广东省是一个专注于创意产业的省份……它是推动创意议程的最佳源泉。”

;国际货币基金组织总裁周五猛烈抨击美国政府让世界陷入困境由于乔·拜登总统与该国共和党之间的债务上限僵局而导致的“焦虑”状态。

;

;克里斯塔利娜·格奥尔基耶娃称美国经济为“我们所有人乘坐的船”，她说她不断在国际舞台上回答有关美国可能违约后果的问题。

;

;“美国国债市场是全球金融体系稳定的支柱，”她说。 “你拉锚，世界经济——我们所有人乘坐的轮船——正处于波涛汹涌、更糟糕的是未知水域。”

;

;违约将“不可避免地”导致经济收缩格奥尔基耶娃补充说，美国和世界经济对最近才开始从冠状病毒大流行中复苏并容易受到俄罗斯对乌克兰战争影响的经济体造成“冲击接连不断的冲击”。

;

;关于债务上限的讨论白宫和共和党众议院议长凯文麦卡锡之间的僵局在过去一周一直持续，双方都表示取得了进展，但尚未在所谓的“X-date”之前达成协议，届时美国财政部将耗尽资金

;

;“让每个人都感到沮丧的是，决策者手中的一个可以解决的问题继续拖延到第 12 个小时，”格奥尔基耶娃说。

;

;“我们都读过关于灰姑娘必须在午夜准时离开舞会的童话故事，我们正处于这个时刻，”她说。

;

;“在我们的马车变成南瓜之前，我们能不能请解决这个问题？我们面临的不仅仅是一只鞋子的损失。”

;

;IMF 表示，亚太地区将在 2023 年引领全球增长，得益于中国经济的反弹

;

;格奥尔基耶娃淡化了这种破坏华盛顿的对峙对全球资本市场产生了影响，将其描述为“对一些利基市场的价格产生了一点影响，而且……没有 [等于] 任何意义”。

;

;但是，“现在最重要的影响是全世界对一些本来不应该成为问题的事情感到焦虑”，她说。

;

;国际货币基金组织总裁恳请华盛顿决策者改变旨在避免借贷限制的制度有可能破坏全球市场的边缘政策。

;

;国会可以让借款限额自动与其批准的拨款数额相匹配，而不是独立于导致批准白宫预算的年度谈判来设定债务上限年度支出账单，她说。

;亨利·基辛格 5 月 27 日将迎来 100 岁生日。在一些人看来，前美国总统国家安全顾问兼国务卿以 1970 年代破冰访华、穿梭中东外交以及与前苏联的缓和演习为幕后外交的缩影。

;

;在我看来，他一生所追求的东西比以往任何时候都更加重要。我们所处的时代，用美国参谋长联席会议上将马克·米尔利的话来说，“我们所有人都应该重新承诺防止这种[类似二战]的可怕灾难，并努力解决除使用大国战争所带来的暴力程度”。

;

;为了防止这样的战争再次爆发，我们需要冷静的外交，而不是公开的争吵。我们需要更多地对困难问题进行坦诚的幕后讨论，减少“扩音器外交”，引用英国驻香港和澳门总领事布莱恩·戴维森 (Brian Davidson) 的话说，他本月早些时候在接受《华盛顿邮报》采访时谈到了英国的与中国的关系以及他希望与香港的关系翻开新篇章的希望。

;

;幕后交流的必要性在崔天凯——中国驻美时间最长的大使到2021 年退休——在一年前为庆祝基辛格 99 岁生日而举行的在线研讨会上发表讲话。王毅外长也在此次活动上发表了讲话，罗伯特·佐利克 (Robert Zoellick) 曾在 2005 年担任美国副国务卿期间敦促中国成为“负责任的利益攸关方”。

;

;崔说他是“担心我们之间的通信质量”。 “有时候，政治表演太多了……而不是实质性的政策交流，”他说，并补充说美国和中国需要“坐下来进行真正的讨论”，包括面对面的对话，而不仅仅是在线。< /p>;

;自从他的博士论文“重建的世界：梅特涅、卡斯尔雷和 1812-22 年的和平问题”以来，基辛格致力于探索拿破仑战争后 19 世纪的欧洲如何获得 100 年的和平，基辛格考虑到核武器的威慑力，他已经生活了大约 70 年，痴迷于当代国际关系中的力量平衡。

;

;当“面对热核灭绝的威胁”时，他写道，“实现和平应成为压倒一切的关切”。但是，正如基辛格所说，复仇女神通过“过于彻底地回应他的祈祷”来惩罚人类，这意味着这一努力变得复杂起来，这意味着当和平失败时，人类本应用来确保自身安全的最终力量可以在世界末日中将其消灭。

;

;为什么中国针对乌克兰冲突的务实和平方案可能也是最好的

;

;事情似乎并没有发生太大变化。在苏联的位置上，美国将中国视为它认为有意图和能力挑战其全球领导地位的对手。两国之间储存的核武器，以及准备从俄罗斯发射井发射的核武器，可能比 40 年前冷战达到顶峰时更容易摧毁地球，因此第二次冷战的明显到来值得关注

;

;话虽如此，美国国家安全顾问杰克·沙利文 (Jake Sullivan) 和现任中国最高外交官王毅本月早些时候在维也纳举行会谈时，或许我们可以保持谨慎乐观。

;

;两天时间里，双方共商谈了8个多小时，台湾、乌克兰等关键问题被列为重点。双方都将讨论描述为“坦诚”、“实质性”和“建设性”，并都强调他们愿意保持这一重要的战略沟通渠道。

;

;回顾最近发生的事件可能会表明有一些早在维也纳会议之前，默契就已经存在。

;

;继 2 月在美国领空发现据称是中国间谍气球之后，美国众议院议长迈克·加拉格尔 (Mike Gallagher) 进行了激烈的官方交流。代表中国问题特别委员会称美中竞争是“生存斗争”，国务院官员里克·沃特斯悄悄前往香港、上海和北京与中国学者和官员进行低调会谈

;

;也许更具指示性的是最近在台湾问题上的微妙互动。许多人对美国前众议院议长南希·佩洛西去年 8 月访问台湾记忆犹新，当台湾总统蔡英文会见众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡和国会议员随行人员时，人们担心北京会强烈反对。美国上个月。

;

;不过，事实证明，中国的反应比预期的要谨慎。洪都拉斯在蔡英文访问之前将其与台北的外交承认改为北京可能是一个重要的发展。没有关于美国试图阻止洪都拉斯采取行动的报道。也许华盛顿没有这样做是为了换取中国在洛杉矶而不是台北举行的蔡-麦卡锡会议上的克制。

;

;快进到上周。习近平主席在西安主持与中亚国家的峰会，而美国总统拜登则在日本广岛参加一年一度的七国集团峰会，领导人在会上认识到“坦诚接触并直接向中国表达关切的重要性”。

;

;当然，这是美中之间的又一轮较量。然而，我们有充分的理由保持乐观，正如基辛格在最近接受《经济学人》采访时所说的那样，“中国和美国在没有正式宣布任何事情的情况下，将力求保持克制”。

;中国商务部部长王文涛在密歇根州底特律与美国贸易代表凯瑟琳戴伊会面周五，继续就世界最大的两个经济体之间的贸易紧张局势恢复高层面对面会谈。

;

;会谈是在王毅周四在华盛顿会见美国商务部长吉娜·雷蒙多之后举行的。

;

;王与戴的会面是在底特律亚太经合组织会议期间举行的。商务部周五发表声明说，双方就“经贸关系和共同关心的地区和多边问题”进行了“坦诚、务实和深入”的交流，并同意继续沟通。

;

;“中方就美国对华经贸政策、经贸领域涉台问题、印太经济框架、301关税等关键问题提出关切，”文中写道。;

;在 5 月 13 日于斯德哥尔摩举行的欧盟印太部长级论坛上，欧盟重申致力于通过其全球门户倡议加强与印太地区的联系与合作。欧洲计划对该地区的基础设施建设进行战略投资，2023 年及以后将启动 20 多个旗舰项目。

;

;仅仅六天后，习近平主席主持了首届中国-中亚与哈萨克斯坦、吉尔吉斯斯坦、塔吉克斯坦、土库曼斯坦和乌兹别克斯坦领导人会晤。 “一带一路”倡议提出以来，中国与中亚五国贸易增长迅速，去年达到702亿美元，同比增长40%。

;

;作为东西方全球基础设施投资争夺战升温，有人将全球门户视为欧盟对中国“一带一路”倡议的回应。后者于 2013 年推出，通过海路和陆路将中国与亚洲、非洲和欧洲连接起来。创造贸易和投资机会以促进与伙伴国的经济增长被认为是中国外交政策的核心组成部分。

;

;虽然中国的倡议因缺乏透明度、环境影响和债务陷阱外交而受到批评, Global Gateway 试图通过强调对面向未来、对环境负责的基础设施的投资来提供替代方案。该倡议基于可持续性、开放性和遵守人权的原则。

;

;随着西方世界的大部分国家重新考虑其对中国的经济依赖，欧盟正试图加强其在印太地区的足迹地区。在欧盟委员会主席乌尔苏拉·冯德莱恩的领导下，欧盟正在采取措施对抗中国日益增长的政治和经济影响力。

;

;该倡议计划在 2021 年至 2027 年间筹集 3000 亿欧元（3242 亿美元）用于投资于数字、气候和能源、交通、卫生、教育和研究连通性倡议，以巩固欧洲的发展融资，重点放在基础设施开发和连通性上。

;

;它基于民主价值观将自己定位为具有独特的欧洲风味、平等伙伴关系、环境可持续性、安全可靠的基础设施和私营部门的整合。

;

;鉴于全球门户的起步相对较晚，尚不清楚它将如何与一带一路竞争，有哪些资源它将与其他新兴倡议合作以及如何合作。欧盟正在努力让批评者相信该计划可以在长期内与中国竞争。

;

;未能兑现巨大承诺会导致声誉损失。 The EU does not have a good track record of leveraging private finance for initiatives outside Europe, and it is unclear whether member states will back the Global Gateway with public cash. Private-sector engagement is also questionable and will be based on risk-reward calculations that could be difficult to reconcile with existing development cooperation norms.

;

;Furthermore, the potentially divergent objectives of the Global Gateway and development policy goals highlight an obvious contradiction. For example, the obvious inconsistencies between helping authoritarian governments with big infrastructure projects while promoting the value-based nature of the EU's development policy and democracy-assistance schemes.

;

;Belt and road plan's 'long-term prospects' at risk in Southeast Asia: study

;

;One major criticism of the belt and road has been the tendency for participating countries to incur substantial debts to finance infrastructure projects that might not be economically viable. It also has been attacked for its lack of transparency and accountability. Numerous projects have been shrouded in secrecy and caused severe ecological damage.

;

;Large-scale infrastructure initiatives require careful planning, transparency and accountability to be economically viable. In addition to exercising caution with large-scale debt financing, it is also important to carefully consider the environmental impact of projects.

;

;The Global Gateway aims to address these shortcomings by offering opportunities for inclusive and sustainable development through targeted investments in a variety of sectors. While promising to adhere to European social and environmental standards, it faces challenges in terms of project details and financing.

;

;To gain the support of participating countries, it is essential to address these challenges and ensure transparency, clarity and robust implementation. It will be crucial to navigate the current geopolitical complexities to establish partnerships to realise the vision.

;

;Some 40 investment programmes have been given the green light in sub-Saharan Africa, Latin America and the Asia-Pacific as part of the initiative. In Africa, the Global Gateway envisions infrastructure initiatives that can improve connectivity, stimulate trade and raise living standards throughout the continent. It can help strengthen partnerships and cooperation, and lead to tangible benefits, including increased investment, technology transfer, capacity development and enhanced regional integration.

;

;For some, the Global Gateway is a competitor to the belt and road, with an emphasis on investment in environmentally responsible, future-oriented infrastructure. The EU wants the initiative to be unique and independent of China's efforts, surpassing them through transparency, good governance, democratic values, “links, not dependencies” and sustainable infrastructure.

;

;If the EU wishes to achieve strategic sovereignty, it must align its actions with its goals. Nearshoring processes are difficult and costly, necessitating significant funding as well as strong political commitment. If the EU acts swiftly, the Global Gateway offers an ideal opportunity to do so.

;

;As the Group of 7 leaders met in Hiroshima to put up a united front against Russia's aggression in Ukraine and to counter China's “economic weaponisation” through debt financing, it seems that the “clash of civilisations” is happening on all fronts.

; Sat, 27 May 2023 01:20:02 +0800 Dismissed US case shows divide within Tibetan diaspora – and the thin line Beijing makes it walkhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/3221998/dismissed-us-case-shows-divide-within-tibetan-diaspora-and-thin-line-beijing-makes-it-walk?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.27 00:01;
;;

;When the US Justice Department first accused New York police officer Baimadajie Angwang of collecting information on fellow Tibetans for the Chinese government in September 2020, the Tibetan diaspora was rocked – but also comforted.

;

;For years they had suspected Beijing was spying on them. Finally, it seemed, US authorities were taking their concerns seriously.

;

;Angwang, 36, soon found himself indicted by a grand jury and jailed for six months at the height of the Covid-19 pandemic, regarded as a traitor by both the Tibetan and American communities he called his own.

;

;But about two years later, when the government dropped charges “in the interests of justice” before trial, it became apparent that the spy novel-esque saga may not have been what it seemed.

;

;What unfolded was a story of the thin line between the accommodations ordinary people feel compelled to make when dealing with the Chinese government and the acts of a willing foreign agent – and of a divided diaspora caught in a rivalry between two superpowers.

;

;

;

;Beijing considers Tibet a long-standing Chinese territory, but many Tibetans call for independence, arguing that their homeland was illegally annexed in 1951.

;

;For many Tibetans on the US east coast, Angwang was a walking red flag – he didn't speak Tibetan very well, used a sinocised name, and once asked the staff to remove a Tibetan flag from a community centre in the New York City borough of Queens. On top of that, for a small diaspora community, barely anyone had heard of him or had a direct connection to him.

;

;But they accepted his presence because he was in law enforcement and said he wanted to help the community.

;

;Born in a Tibetan part of Sichuan province, Angwang – his Tibetan name is Pema Dhargyal Ngawang – applied for asylum in the US as a teenager on a student visa in 2005, claiming that Chinese police beat him for speaking out against the government's treatment of Tibetans.

;

;While his parents and brother remained in China, he served in the US Marine Corps and became an army reservist and US citizen. At the time of his arrest, Angwangworked in a community affairs unit for the New York Police Department in Queens.

;

;Before 2019, Angwang did not interact much with New York's Tibetan community. “As a police officer, my job is very busy … I also have a beautiful daughter so I don't have that much free time to go out,” he said in an interview with the South China Morning Post.

;

;“But as a Tibetan, I like to help the community,” he said, explaining why he visited the Tibetan centre in 2019.

;

;Recounting the flag incident, Angwang said he was trying to help, not undermine, the centre. “They were organising a New Year event, so they asked me for my opinion and I didn't see any American flags.

;

;“I said 'you guys are inviting different guests … We are in America, would be nice to put some American flags out.'”

;

;

;

;Angwang was charged with one count of acting as a foreign government agent without notifying the US government, and three counts related to not disclosing foreign ties on his national security background check.

;

;In charging documents, prosecutors said that Angwang, acting at the “direction and control” of Chinese officials, reported on fellow Tibetans, spotted and assessed potential intelligence sources and used his position to provide the Chinese consulate access to senior NYPD officials.

;

;The evidence came from 55 wiretapped calls and text exchanges between Angwang and an official of Tibetan heritage at the Chinese consulate in New York from June 2018 to March 2020. It is unclear what prompted the wiretap, but according to the criminal complaint, earlier phone records also showed 53 exchanges between Angwang and another consulate official from 2014 to 2017.

;

;The complaint portrayed the Tibetan official as a “handler” and Angwang his “asset”, claiming that Angwang “received tasks from and reported back to” the official.

;

;One translated wiretap excerpt quoted Angwang suggesting that the official tell his superiors about their relationship: “Let them know, you have recruited one in the police department.”

;

;The complaint also noted Angwang's multiple references to the official as “boss”, as well as an instance in which he sought advice on whether he should appear on a show associated with Falun Gong, a spiritual movement banned in China.

;

;Yet the term “boss” is ambiguous, as its everyday usage in Mandarin does not always connote a hierarchical relationship.

;

;Excerpts also show Angwang, rather than the official, taking the lead – offering repeatedly to help “boost” the official's career – and the official occasionally declining his suggestions.

;

;Angwang identified potential contacts for the official, including a Tibetan-American politician and a “neglected” Tibetan group known as Shugden worshippers.

;

;At one point, Angwang suggested the official accompany him to the Tibetan community centre. At another, he recommended that the official attend an NYPD event to “raise our country's soft power”. Both times, the official expressed reluctance.

;

;Angwang's lawyer, John Carman, also noted other factors that argued against Angwang being a spy: he never mentioned his US military ties to the consulate official, and used his personal cellphone instead of a burner phone to contact the official.

;

;Angwang said that the official he spoke to was responsible for issuing visas to Tibetans, and that he was just following the typical process for overseas Tibetans applying for a Chinese visa.

;

;“I'm a human being. I want to see my family,” Angwang told the Post.

;

;Angwang's “solicitous and accommodating tone” towards the consulate should be read in that context, Carman said, noting that Angwang had sought – and was refused – a 10-year visa to China.

;

;“In my mind, I'm just going to apply my visa and that's their process … at the same time, I was … advocating for myself and the Tibetans who want to visit China,” Angwang said.

;

;“Making friends” with the official, he added, was “part of the process”.

;

;He did not discuss the contents of his pre-2018 conversations with the consulate.

;

;The Chinese embassy in Washington declined to comment on visa procedures and referred to a foreign ministry statement from April opposing the US's “false” narrative of “transnational repression”.

;

;

;

;While Angwang's prosecution came amid growing US concern over transnational repression by Beijing, it was atypical for targeting a member of an ethnic minority considered oppressed by Beijing.

;

;Robert Barnett, the founder of the modern Tibetan studies programme at Columbia University, concluded that the case was “likely a distortion” after reading the complaint.

;

;As a researcher of sensitive topics in China, Barnett said, he could easily relate to Angwang's posturing.

;

;“That's what many people dealing with the Chinese embassy are in – the position of a supplicant,” he said, noting that officials “will sometimes try to get information or some promise of support in return” for granting access.

;

;Like Barnett, Tsering Shakya, a Tibetan scholar at the University of British Columbia, initially doubted the case against Angwang and questioned the value that someone in his position could add.

;

;“There is not a single piece of information he [is] said to have reported to his handler that is [not in] the public domain” he wrote in 2020.

;

;Clifford Fishman, a law professor emeritus at the Catholic University of America, noted that human intelligence gathering can help make sense of huge amounts of other data.

;

;But as a former prosecutor, he called it notable that such a high-profile case was dismissed without explanation: “The government tends to be very methodical and careful before obtaining an indictment in a big case.”

;

;In federal cases involving national security, Fishman said, charges may be dropped to avoid state secrets from being disclosed. Occasionally, though, a case is “so badly bungled that the charges are dropped to avoid embarrassment”.

;

;The Justice Department said in January that the evidence that led them to request dismissal was “classified” and has since declined to comment.

;

;

;

;For their part, members of the Tibetan diaspora in New York were not relieved when Angwang's case was dropped.

;

;Some questioned the details of his defence and took solace in the fact that the case was dismissed “without prejudice”, meaning it could be reintroduced with new evidence.

;

;Tenzin Namgyal, president of the Regional Tibetan Youth Congress of New York and New Jersey, wrote to Senator Charles Schumer of New York seeking an investigation.

;

;Contending there had been a rise in Chinese “handlers” across the US, Namgyal wrote that “Tibetans are really concern[ed], anxious and saddened” by the case's dismissal.

;

;The International Campaign for Tibet, a Washington-based advocacy group, noted that the dismissal did not disprove Beijing's active monitoring of Tibetans abroad. It cited a 2018 case in Sweden where a Tibetan was convicted after being paid by Chinese officials to provide information on fellow Tibetans.

;

;But Tencho Gyatso, the group's president, also acknowledged that it was not uncommon for Tibetans to want to visit relatives in China once they obtained a foreign passport.

;

;Ethnic Tibetans who seek a visa to China go through a separate, highly scrutinised process, she said.

;

;“Every embassy has a United Front person and the Tibetan visa applications go through” them,” she said, referring to the Chinese Communist Party unit tasked with strengthening adherence to the party within and outside China.

;

;“The Chinese embassy selectively gives visas [and] creates confusion,” she added.

;

;Barnett said that Beijing officials seek to sow division among Tibetans, particularly between what they call “patriotic overseas compatriots” and the “Dalai clique” – Tibetans who they consider supporters of “separatism”. In bringing the Angwang case, he said, the Justice Department helped magnify existing divides.

;

;Even within the small US diaspora community, Barnett said, a “big division” exists between Tibetans who were born or raised in India or Nepal and those like Angwang who left China later in life. Tibetans who are most publicly active in the US are generally part of the India group, he said.

;

;About 26,000 Tibetans live in the US, according to a 2020 study by the Central Tibetan Administration, the Tibetan government-in-exile based in India. Half of them reside in the New York and New Jersey area.

;

;Tibetans from the outside had “tended in earlier decades to be wary of people who came from China”, Barnett said. “While relations within the community have improved in recent years, [this] case will not have helped with that process”.

;

;Language can be a lightning rod for distrust, Barnett noted. Angwang's fluency in Mandarin thus made him suspect to the community he tried to engage. His Tibetan dialect, which reportedly reflected a remote, quiet region called Gyalrong, was also foreign to many of the active diaspora.

;

;

;

;Until the charges were dropped, Angwang's support came only from close friends, family and fellow police officers and Marine Corps veterans. He remains on paid administrative leave from the police department.

;

;Angwang is convinced that he was unfairly targeted because he is Asian, but it was only after his case was dismissed that Asian-American groups began speaking out in support – a stark contrast to the outcry that attended several federal cases against Chinese researchers under the Justice Department's now-shuttered “China Initiative”.

;

;“It's sending the wrong picture to American people, that Asian people, particularly Asian immigrants, cannot be trusted,” he said of his case.

;

;Going forward, Angwang said, he has a new goal: to fight against the “demonisation of Asian people” and government “abuse of power”.

;A newly released cache of FBI files has revealed a potential plot to assassinate Queen Elizabeth during her 1983 visit to California.

;

;The possible threat followed a phone call made by “a man who claimed that his daughter had been killed in Northern Ireland by a rubber bullet”, according to the document that also refers to a bar frequented by Irish Republican Army (IRA) sympathisers.

;

;The queen and her husband Prince Philip visited the west coast of the United States in February and March 1983, and the trip passed off without incident.

;

;Four years earlier in 1979, IRA paramilitaries opposed to British rule in Northern Ireland killed Louis Mountbatten, the last colonial governor of India and an uncle of Philip, in a bomb attack.

;

;

;The file states that the man claimed he was going to attempt to harm the queen “either by dropping some object off the Golden Gate Bridge onto the royal yacht Britannia when it sails underneath”.

;

;Alternatively he “would attempt to kill Queen Elizabeth when she visited Yosemite National Park”, they added.

;

;A separate file among the documents, dated 1989, pointed out that while the FBI was unaware of any specific threats against the queen, “the possibility of threats against the British monarchy is ever present from the Irish Republican Army”.

;

;The queen, who died last September aged 96, had previously been reported to have been the target of other assassination plots.

;

;In 1970, suspected IRA sympathisers unsuccessfully attempted to derail her train west of Sydney, while in 1981 the IRA tried to bomb her on a visit to Shetland, off the northeast coast of Scotland.

;

;In the same year, a mentally disturbed teenager fired a single shot towards the queen's car during a visit to New Zealand.

;

;Another teenager fired six blanks at her during the Trooping the Colour parade in central London.
